head.title: Ligtenberg to the Rescue As the Braves Hang On

hedline.hl1: Ligtenberg to the Rescue As the Braves Hang On

block.p: Andruw Jones, Brian Jordan and Chipper Jones hit home runs in a cooled-down Enron Field, leading the Atlanta Braves to a 6-5 victory over the Houston Astros yesterday.

The Braves' reliever John Rocker walked the bases loaded in the ninth inning and was pulled. Kerry Ligtenberg escaped the jam without allowing a run, getting Richard Hidalgo to ground into a game-ending double play.
Andruw Jones, Brian Jordan and Chipper Jones hit home runs in a cooled-down Enron Field, leading the Atlanta Braves to a 6-5 victory over the Houston Astros yesterday.

The Braves' reliever John Rocker walked the bases loaded in the ninth inning and was pulled. Kerry Ligtenberg escaped the jam without allowing a run, getting Richard Hidalgo to ground into a game-ending double play.
The one-run loss was Houston's 13th in 14 games this season.

The Astros lost more than the game. Moises Alou left the game with tightness in his left quadriceps muscle one day after outfielder Roger Cedeno was placed on the 15-day disabled list. Alou was listed as day to day.
The Braves got the early lead in the first regular-season game played at Enron Field with the roof closed. It was 72 degrees inside with the air conditioning while temperatures outside hit the 90's.

Rocker walked the first two batters in the ninth, threw a wild pitch and then intentionally walked Ken Caminiti. Ligtenberg relieved and retired Daryle Ward on a shallow fly ball and, on a full count, got Hidalgo to bounce into a double play for his his third save.
ROCKIES 7, PIRATES 6: In Denver, Todd Helton hit two home runs, including a leadoff shot in the ninth inning that lifted Colorado.
Helton tied the score, 5-5, with a three-run homer in the fifth.
Helton, who ended an 0-for-13 slide with two hits Friday, went
4 for 4, raising his average to .406.
Jason Kendall, with his father watching from the Colorado bullpen, went 4 for 5 with 3 runs scored, and Wil Cordero added a two-run homer for the Pirates.
Colorado erased an early 5-0 deficit and got an impressive effort from relievers Julian Tavarez and Gabe White (4-0). The two held Pittsburgh to one run and three hits in four and a third innings.
The bullpen set the stage for Helton as he hit the first pitch from Jason Christiansen (1-3) into the bullpen beyond right field for his 15th homer of the season.
CUBS 3, GIANTS 2: Jose Nieves's sacrifice fly in the 11th inning gave Chicago a victory at San Francisco, just the Cubs' eighth victory in 24 road games this season.
Henry Rodriguez opened the 11th with a double off Aaron Fultz (1-1). The pinch-runner Chad Meyers moved to third on a groundout and, after a walk, scored on Nieves's fly to right.
Daniel Garibay (1-1) pitched two hitless innings for the victory. Rick Aguilera pitched the 11th for his eighth save in 12 chances.
DIAMONDBACKS 7, BREWERS 3: Tony Womack extended his hitting streak to 22 games and scored twice, and Arizona stretched its team-record home winning string to 11.
Luis Gonzalez also homered for Arizona, which has won five straight over all. Milwaukee has lost four in a row.

Steve Finley hit his 18th homer and drove in three runs, raising his National League-leading runs-batted-in total to 51. His two-run homer in the fifth inning tied the score, and Jay Bell singled home the go-ahead run in the sixth.
Armando Reynoso (3-4) allowed two runs in six innings. Byung-Hyun Kim retired the last five batters for his fifth save in six chances.
